sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Hisuian Arcanine is a strong wallbreaker, capable of denting many physically defensive Pokemon such as Scream Tail while taking advantage of Magic Guard by using Head Smash and Flare Blitz in combination with Life Orb without any drawbacks. Close Combat allows Hisuian Arcanine to hit Ting-Lu and Well-Baked Body Iron Treads, while Will-O-Wisp threatens burns on checks like physically defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Extreme Speed is useful priority that picks off weakened targets, Stealth Rock allows Hisuian Arcanine to act as an offensive entry hazard setter that pressures Corviknight and Iron Treads, and Flame Charge boosts its Speed to thwart potential revenge killers. As Hisuian Arcanine places a lot of pressure on physical walls, other physical cleaners like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao can be partnered with Hisuian Arcanine to clean up after it has broken those walls while providing speed control. Since Hisuian Arcanine is checked by Garchomp and bulky Water-types like Quaquaval, Refrigerate Regieleki makes a good partner for it by forcing these Pokemon out, pivoting Hisuian Arcanine in, and helping to deal with faster threats through its raw Speed. Hisuian Arcanine's middling Speed makes slow pivots like Corviknight good partners due to their ability to bring it in safely; alternatively, Corviknight's dual screens set allows Arcanine to take a hit and strike back.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Paldean Tauros-F secures a niche in AAA thanks to Desolate Land, which allows it to take advantage of its powerful STAB moves, decent Speed tier, and great Attack. Raging Bull is a consistent STAB option with no drawbacks, whereas Flare Blitz provides the power necessary to 2HKO particularly sturdy foes like Ting-Lu. Earthquake lets Paldean Tauros-F hit Skeledirge, which otherwise blanks it. Paldean Tauros-F is limited by its good but not great Speed tier and bulky Fire-resistant foes like Dondozo and Gyarados, so ways to deal with its offensive and defensive counterplay are important. Fast Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Iron Moth can force out foes like Kilowattrel and Sandy Shocks. Speed control via Thunder Wave from allies like Blissey and Scream Tail is useful in deterring faster foes like Greninja. Electric-types like Rotom-W and Kilowattrel can consistently force out the sturdy Water-types that threaten Paldean Tauros-F while bringing it in on their switch-ins like Roaring Moon and Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Primordial Sea
sets.description: Zapdos, with its solid defensive typing and strong Special Attack, is a potent pivot that is able to check Corviknight, Galarian Zapdos, and Talonflame, as well as potent offensive Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge thanks to Primordial Sea. Primordial Sea also enables Zapdos to spam its strong STAB moves in Hurricane and Thunder, which allow it to OHKO offensive threats such as Meowscarada, Quaquaval, and Talonflame; Zapdos also pressures common RegenVest users like Meloetta with U-turn. Zapdos can opt to go for a more bulky spread of 252 HP / 4 SpA / 252 Spe to better check strong Fighting-types like Slither Wing and Galarian Zapdos. Zapdos is a good partner for offensive Pokemon like Slither Wing, Meowscarada, and Zamazenta-C, as it can bait in targets like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta that they can take advantage of. Zapdos also pairs well with Corviknight, as Primordial Sea's Fire immunity allows Corviknight to run more physically defensive abilities such as Fluffy and Intimidate. Zapdos can struggle against bulky Ground-types like Regenerator Garchomp and Landorus-T, so pairing it with an attacker like Chien-Pao is recommended.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Galarian Zapdos is a fearsome wallbreaker that can overwhelm common defensive cores. Close Combat and Brave Bird have fantastic neutral coverage and power, OHKOing virtually everything short of a physical wall and 2HKOing those, further amplified by Choice Band. Thunderous Kick overpowers some of its few checks like Fluffy Corviknight, which could otherwise stall it out. Adamant is the preferred nature to have a high chance to 2HKO Intimidate Corviknight after Leftovers recovery, but Jolly is an option to Speed tie Zapdos and outspeed Jolly Hisuian Arcanine. Galarian Zapdos pairs exceptionally well with special pivots like Hisuian Electrode and Kilowattrel, as they can draw in special walls like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta for it. Fast physical cleaners like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada appreciate Galarian Zapdos blowing through physical walls for them. Since Galarian Zapdos is prone to Stealth Rock, opposing Rocky Helmet, and Brave Bird recoil wearing it down, it appreciates pivots like Iron Treads and Corviknight that can also clear Stealth Rock and Wish passers like Scream Tail. Galarian Zapdos is relatively slow and easily revenge killed, so it relies on a sturdy defensive core like Intimidate Corviknight and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra to switch out to.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Galarian Zapdos serves as a potent physical threat that can either wear down and outlast its checks with U-turn or set up and serve as an excellent wincon with Bulk Up or Agility. U-turn allows Galarian Zapdos to maintain momentum in face of switch-ins like Fluffy Corviknight, while Taunt allows Galarian Zapdos to deny defensive walls recovery and outlast them. Bulk Up provides immediate wallbreaking power, while Agility allows Galarian Zapdos to outpace would-be revenge killers; Adamant is the preferred nature on Agility sets. Offensive special threats like Refridgerate Regieleki and Primordial Sea Inteleon serve well as teammates, appreciating Galarian Zapdos's ability to threaten special walls like Hisuian Goodra while also threatening Galarian Zapdos's own checks like Fluffy Corviknight and Zapdos, both able to pivot on their respective walls to create opportunities to wallbreak or accumulate entry hazard chip. Fast physical threats like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada also serve well as teammates to pressure and overload physical walls as well as handle faster offensive threats that Galarian Zapdos cannot. Galarian Zapdos also partners well with defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight and RegenVest Meloetta which can safely pivot Galarian Zapdos in. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp that help wear down its help wear down Galarian Zapdos's checks and can take hits from faster offensive Pokemon; alternatively, Galarian Zapdos can partner well with dual screens support from the likes of Prankster Mew and Corviknight to help facilitate setup sets.

sets.name: Choice Scarf Regenerator
sets.description: Choice Scarf Regenerator Mew is a strong utility pivot that checks fast physical attackers with the combination of Will-O-Wisp + Volt Switch while still pressuring defensive cores with entry hazards and Trick. Ice Beam can be used as an alternative to Spikes to pressure Pokemon like Garchomp and Landorus-T. Trick can be used to neutralize support Pokemon and defensive pivots like Corviknight while serving as an emergency stop to bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Enamorus-T. 136 Speed EVs with a Timid nature ensure that Mew outspeeds Chien Pao, Hisuian Electrode, and +1 Jolly Quaquaval, as well as positive natured Slither Wing and Heatran after Trick. Bulky teammates like Corviknight, Garganacl, Zapdos, and Skeledirge benefit from Mew's ability to spread burns and set hazards, allowing them to absorb more hits from physical attackers and whittle down these attackers more quickly; Mew can also pressure fast attackers like Meowscarada and Talonflame that they struggle with. Additionally, late-game cleaners like Chien-Pao, Hisuian Arcanine, and Quaquaval benefit from Mew's ability to chip defensive switch-ins and hinder walls by giving them a Choice Scarf.

sets.name: Prankster
sets.description: Prankster Mew is a good dual screens lead for hyper offense teams thanks to its good bulk, Speed, and movepool. Taunt blocks foes such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Iron Treads from setting entry hazards, Corviknight from clearing screens with Defog, and opposing setup sweepers like Volcarona from taking advantage of free turns. U-turn lets it pivot into its teammates and potentially re-set screens later in the game. Stealth Rock or Spikes can be used over U-turn to chip foes for teammates to KO. 96 Speed EVs and a Jolly Nature ensure that Mew always moves first against opposing leads like Prankster Corviknight and Masquerain, allowing Mew to hinder them with Taunt. Prankster Mew should only be used as a dual screens lead on hyper offense teams. Teammates such as Chien-Pao, Polteageist, Volcarona, and Roaring Moon all appreciate screens, which allow them to easily set up and make them less susceptible to revenge killers. The aforementioned Pokemon also provide good options for Mew to pivot into and gain momentum. Dark-type Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Meowscarada, and Chien-Pao are immune to Prankster Taunt and can take advantage of Mew, so counters to them such as Zamazenta-C and Triage users, like Enamorus-T and Ursaluna, are good teammates.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Slowking serves as a decent defensive wall due to its overall good bulk and support movepool, switching into various physical attackers such as Talonflame, Cinderace, and Quaquaval. Chilly Reception lets Slowking pivot into teammates in order to gain momentum, notably Chien-Pao. Slowking's low Speed stat with 0 Speed IVs allows it to switch into a favorable teammate after pivoting. Surf is a reliable STAB move that most notably deals huge damage to Sandy Shocks, Talonflame, and Iron Moth. Ice Beam threatens Garchomp and stops it from using Slowking as a setup fodder. Thunder Wave can be used in order to cripple Iron Moth and Roaring Moon that usually switch into Slowking and can pressure it. Intimidate is the preferred choice of ability, as it combines well with Slowking's ability to pivot, making it difficult to KO. Fluffy can be used as an alternative in order to deal with Roaring Moon better. Rocky Helmet punishes U-turn users such as Cinderace and Quaquaval from freely pivoting against Slowking, while Heavy-Duty Boots keeps Slowking healthy. Slowking fits best on balance teams where it can switch into aforementioned Pokemon while also being able to pivot into teammates like Chien-Pao and Kingambit, providing them a good setup opportunity.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Assault Vest Donphan is a solid special pivot that can check the likes of Sandy Shocks while also removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Knock Off cripples switch-ins and can support offensive teammates. Body Press is used as a coverage option for Earth Eater Kingambit and Iron Treads, which would otherwise wall Donphan. Offensive Pokemon susceptible to hazards such as Chien-Pao and Dragonite appreciate Donphan's spinning capabilities. Physically defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Garganacl also pair well with Donphan, as it can handle special attackers like Sandy Shocks that threaten them. Donphan can be prone to residual damage, so it's recommended to pair it with a Wish user like Scream Tail or Florges to extend its longevity.

sets.name: Defensive Wall
sets.description: Blissey is a solid specially defensive wall that rounds out stall and balance teams checking powerful special attackers such as Sheer Force Iron Moth and Hydreigon. Vessel of Ruin is a viable option to shore up Blissey's already high Special Defense, while Unaware helps Blissey win the one-on-one against setup sweepers like Quiver Dance Volcarona and Shell Smash Polteageist. Leftovers gives Blissey passive recovery to help stall out foes, but Heavy-Duty Boots is an option on teams with less reliable entry hazard control. Shadow Ball hits Polteageist. Unaware + Calm Mind and Soft-Boiled allows Blissey to become a bulky sweeper against passive Pokemon such as Scream Tail, but Thunder Wave allows Blissey to spread paralysis to better support the team. Due to its frail physical bulk, Blissey appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Garganacl, which can handle physical sweepers such as Talonflame and Quaquaval. Dondozo is also a suitable teammate, as it can blanket check other physical threats such as Cinderace and Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Tinted Lens
sets.description: Gardevoir is a good special wallbreaker due to a combination of its good Special Attack and Choice Specs. Tinted Lens allows Gardevoir to 2HKO Steel-types such as Iron Treads and Corviknight. Moonblast is its strongest STAB option and OHKOes a plethora of Pokemon such as Garchomp and RegenVest Roaring Moon while also 2HKOing walls such as RegenVest Ting-Lu and Corviknight. Psyshock OHKOes specially defensive Iron Moth and Clodsire and deals huge damage to Blissey. Healing Wish is an useful late-game move that lets Gardevoir gain momentum for its team by healing one of its teammates. Gardevoir can be easily revenge killed by Pokemon such as Slither Wing and Cinderace due to its low Speed, so Pokemon such as Corviknight and Gargancl are good teammates. U-turn users such as Corviknight, Cinderace, and Greninja can pivot and provide Gardevoir with a good opportunity to put huge dents in opposing teams. Entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Clodsire provide additional chip damage, allowing Gardevoir to wallbreak efficiently.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Garchomp is a sterling special wall capable of pivoting into dangerous threats such as Heatran, Iron Moth, Sandy Shocks, and Zapdos. Swords Dance reduces Garchomp's passivity, allowing it to break down walls such as Quaquaval and Landorus-T over time. Garchomp's strong matchup against common entry hazard removers such as Quaquaval, Cinderace, and Well-Baked Body Iron Treads makes it an excellent Stealth Rock setter. Alternatively, if a teammate already carries Stealth Rock, Garchomp can use Spikes to apply more pressure to offensive teams. Dragon Tail deters setup sweepers such as Zamazenta-C and walls such as Corviknight and Ground immunity Iron Treads from taking advantage of Garchomp, while Rock Slide allows Garchomp to hit threats such as Enamorus-T, Zapdos, and Earth Eater Skeledirge. Corviknight is a brilliant partner for Garchomp, taking on dangerous physical attackers such as Galarian Zapdos and Chien-Pao for it, while Garchomp covers its Fire and Electric weaknesses. Blissey can take on the special attackers that can overwhelm Garchomp, such as Sheer Force Iron Moth, Choice Specs Zapdos, and Greninja. Iron Moth checks various threats to Garchomp, such as Corviknight, Scream Tail, and Enamorus-T, and it appreciates Garchomp's ability to beat Hisuian Arcanine and RegenVest users such as Meloetta. Other powerful wallbreakers such as Zapdos, Slither Wing, Hisuian Arcanine, and Volcanion appreciate Garchomp's phazing and entry hazard support to wear down their checks over time.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description: Mixed Garchomp, with its naturally great coverage, good Speed tier, and high-Base Power STAB moves, is a reliable entry hazard setter that deters common removal options from switching in. Life Orb is an option over Leftovers for a harder hit on hazard removers. Draco Meteor provides immediate power against Quaquaval, Earthquake hits non-Earth Eater Iron Treads, and Fire Blast chips Corviknight. A Naive nature allows Garchomp to offensively check Sandy Shocks, Thundurus-T, and the crowded base 100 Speed tier without weakening its attacks. A Naive nature is preferred over Hasty to allow Garchomp to better switch in on common hazard removers. Offensive threats like Iron Moth, Chien-Pao, and Galarian Zapdos greatly appreciate the presence of mixed Garchomp, which disincentivizes common defensive pieces from entering the battle, and for its entry hazards. Similarly, more defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Unaware Scream Tail also appreciate Garchomp outspeeding and heavily damaging offensive threats like non-Choice Scarf Slither Wing, Hisuian Arcanine, and Galarian Zapdos. Mixed Garchomp is vulnerable to faster threats that force it out with super effective moves, like Chien-Pao and Pixilate Scream Tail, and U-turn users that swing momentum in their favor, such as Meowscarada, Iron Moth, and Roaring Moon: slow, bulky pivots that help combat these weaknesses and turn momentum back in your favor, such as Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and slow Iron Treads, are recommended.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Garchomp is an excellent wallbreaker with its great stats and typing, allowing it to set up on many Pokemon like Corviknight, Fluffy Quaquaval, and Zapdos. Stone Edge can be used to OHKO Zapdos and Enamorus-T, while Liquidation can be ran to hit Landorus-T and Earth Eater Iron Treads. Garchomp can provide excellent Stealth Rock support to an offensive team that otherwise would not be able to fit it, especially given it pressures Corviknight and common spinners; alternatively, it can use Poison Jab to 2HKO Unaware Scream Tail. Life Orb provides extra power for benchmarks like 2HKOing Galarian Zapdos with Stone Edge and Fluffy Garchomp with Earthquake, as well as chunking Corviknight harder for its teammates. A Jolly nature is necessary to outspeed key targets like Zapdos, Galarian Zapdos, and Jolly Hisuian Arcanine. Other physically offensive Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Quaquaval appreciate Garchomp weakening shared checks in Scream Tail and Intimidate Corviknight. Garchomp also appreciates screens support from Mew and Corviknight, which allow to set up more easily and beat more Pokemon in a one-on-one; the latter can also slow pivot Garchomp in to preserve its health for later.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description: Magic Guard + Life Orb Lucario is a potent mixed attacker with powerful STAB attacks. Focus Blast can 2HKO special walls such as Blissey and Ting-Lu as well as physically defensive Corviknight after Steel Beam, while Aura Sphere is a weaker but more reliable alternative. Nasty Plot can be used to boost Lucario's wallbreaking ability, while Stone Edge is an alternative option to deal with Talonflame and Volcarona, which resists its STAB combination. Special attackers like Iron Moth and Sandy Shocks appreciate Lucario's ability to reliably break through special walls such as Sand Stream Garganacl and Regenerator Roaring Moon. Additionally, fast physical attackers such as Chien-Pao and Meowscarada also pair well with Lucario, as they can take care of faster threats that Lucario is susceptible to while Lucario breaks through physical walls like Corviknight and Kingambit. Lucario is very frail, so it is recommended to pair it with Pokemon that can safely pivot it in like Corviknight. Lucario can also have a hard time breaking through bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Slowking, so pairing it with a strong Electric-type attacker like Sandy Shocks or Kilowattrel is worthwhile.

sets.name: Fluffy
sets.description: Fluffy Hippowdon is a remarkable physical wall thanks to its defensive stats, reliable recovery in Slack Off, and pure Ground typing, letting it check offensive threats like Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing. Whirlwind prevents foes like Talonflame from setting up. Rocky Helmet punishes the physical attackers it checks and lets it pseudo-spinblock Cyclizar and Iron Treads; alternatively, Leftovers gives it extra recovery without having to waste Slack Off PP. 25 Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight, allowing it to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Specially defensive walls like Corviknight, Florges, and Blissey can compensate for Hippowdon's poor Special Defense and check foes like Chi-Yu and Greninja. In return, they appreciate Hippowdon dealing with Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Glaceon is a potent special attacker that can pressure common specially defensive threats like Garchomp, Roaring Moon, and Toxapex with Ice Beam + Freeze-Dry. Shadow Ball is used for Skeledirge and Scream Tail, while Mud Shot hits Steel-types like Regenerator Tinkaton and can OHKO Iron Moth. 22 Speed EVs allow Glaceon to outspeed Corviknight, and the rest are invested into bulk to better take hits from Body Press Corviknight and Torch Song Skeledirge. Special attackers like Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Iron Moth benefit from Glaceon breaking through special walls like Garchomp and Roaring Moon that they could otherwise struggle with. Glaceon can have a hard time switching in due its poor defensive typing and susceptibility to entry hazards, so having a teammate that can remove hazards and safely pivot it in like Corviknight or Iron Treads is recommended. Glaceon can struggle with bulky Steel-types like Kingambit, so pairing it with a Fighting-type like Lucario or Slither Wing is advised. Glaceon is also slow and would benefit from faster teammates like Choice Scarf Meowscarda that can pressure offensive threats that may threaten it.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Rotom-W can either serve as a strong offensive pivot, revenge killer, and potential late-game cleaner with Choice Scarf or as an immediately powerful wallbreaker with Choice Specs. With its dangerous type combination, it dissuades Pokemon that are immune to Water-type attacks such as Desolate Land Iron Moth from switching in through its powerful Electric-type moves while Hydro Pump scares off Ground-types like Ting-Lu. Hadron Engine affords a powerful boost to all its attacks, while Primordial Sea boosts its Water-type attacks even further and grants it an immunity to Fire. Trick and Will-O-Wisp allow Rotom-W to cripple and irritate defensive switch-ins such as Blissey and RegenVest Roaring Moon, while Will-O-Wisp can also provide utility against offensive threats such as Meowscarada. Volt Switch allows Rotom-W to pivot on and maintain momentum against common defensive answers like Regenerator Roaring Moon and pairs well with offensive threats like Choice Band Slither Wing and Chien-Pao. Rotom-W also can partner well with other powerful special threats like Hydreigon and Hadron Engine Iron Moth, which can combine with it to overload common special walls. Being mainly an offensive pivot, Rotom-W also appreciates entry hazard removal from the likes of Iron Treads and Corviknight, which both double as pivots that allow Rotom-W to safely get in.

sets.name: Desolate Land
sets.description: A set with maximum Special Attack investment and a Modest nature can be used instead for more offensive pressure.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Heatran is a strong mixed attacker that threatens massive damage to the format's defensive pivots with its powerful Steel- and Fire-type attacks. Steel Beam is Heatran's best offensive option, as Magic Guard negates its massive recoil, while Flare Blitz acts as a strong secondary STAB attack that breaks down Steel-types and special walls like Hisuian Goodra. Power Gem acts as a strong coverage option, targeting common Fire- and Steel-type switch-ins like Skeledirge and Primordial Sea Zapdos. A Mild nature is chosen to maximize both Heatran's physical and special power, and 96 Attack EVs let it 2HKO common RegenVest users like Meloetta and Hisuian Goodra after Stealth Rock damage. 200 Speed EVs let Heatran outspeed Modest Volcanion, and the rest of the available EVs are put into Special Attack to maximize Steel Beam's power. Heatran relies on being able to consistently force foes out to make progress, so bulky entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu can help set up Spikes alongside Heatran's Stealth Rock to consistently chip and punish the opponent's switches. Additionally, to help seal the deal against bulky pivots like Garchomp and fast revenge killers like Chien-Pao, Heatran appreciates teammates like Scream Tail to absorb their hits and have a chance to make progress against them. Finally, offensive teammates like Chien-Pao can take advantage of Heatran's ability to chip switch-ins early-game, as well as defeating Goodra, leading to a more threatening end-game presence.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description: IronPress Heatran trades immediate damage for more defensive utility and sweeping potential, being able to handle common Ground-types like Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Ting-Lu. Lava Plume is preferred over Flamethrower to spread burns against switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra, Magic Guard Quaquaval, and Ting-Lu. IronPress allows Heatran to better take on RegenVest users such as Alolan Muk and Meloetta, Garchomp, and Well-Baked Body Steel-types, most notably Kingambit. Substitute blocks Dragon Tail from Garchomp and Knock Off from Iron Treads, takes advantage of the switches Heatran forces versus foes like Blissey, and also benefits from Iron Defense boosts. 200 Speed EVs and a Timid nature make Heatran outrun Timid Volcanion and Adamant Slither Wing. This Heatran variant is very vulnerable to common Primordial Sea users in Zapdos, Kilowattrel, and Inteleon, so partners that can take them on like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta are mandatory. Primordial Sea Zapdos can switch in against Fire-types such as Iron Moth, Skeledirge, and Ceruledge that threaten Heatran. In return, Heatran takes on RegenVest users that Zapdos struggles to break through. Another Fire-type teammate with Desolate Land like Cinderace, Iron Moth, or Ceruledge appreciates Heatran taking on Ground-types for it, while they can punish Water-types and the aforementioned Primordial Sea users.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Hydreigon serves as a powerful wallbreaker with its powerful STAB attacks and high Special Attack. Mega Launcher + Dragon Pulse or Dark Pulse allows Hydreigon to reliably fire off its boosted STAB moves, while Dragon's Maw + Draco Meteor offers the most wallbreaking potential, chunking special walls such as Sand Stream Garganacl and Clodsire and having a chance to OHKO RegenVest Roaring Moon. U-turn allows Hydreigon to maintain momentum on defensive switch-ins like Blissey, while Focus Blast allows Hydreigon to better break walls like defensive Kingambit and RegenVest Iron Treads. Even with Flash Cannon, Hydreigon struggles against Fairy-types like RegenVest Tinkaton and Florges, so it appreciates partners like Iron Moth and Well-Baked Body Corviknight who can handle them. Hydreigon also suffers from subpar Speed, so it partners well with teammates like Corviknight and Iron Treads, which can pivot and switch into faster offensive threats such as Meowscarada and Chien-Pao. Powerful physical attackers like Choice Band Slither Wing and Swords Dance Cinderace also synergize well with Hydreigon for their ability to threaten and take advantage of Hydreigon's checks like RegenVest Tinkaton and Blissey.

sets.name: Fast Support
sets.description: Volcarona serves as a solid support pokemon with valuable defensive utility to check the likes of Hariyama and Glaceon. Fiery Dance lets Volcarona increase its Special Attack without having to setup, while Flamethrower has more PP and immediate power. U-turn allows Volcarona to maintain momentum, while Quiver Dance serves as an option to go for a potential late-game sweep. Will-O-Wisp cripples switch-ins like Garganacl and is generally great for weakening physical attackers like Quaquaval. Teammates such as Meowscarada and Roaring Moon appreciate Volcarona's ability to sponge priority moves from Slither Wing and Hatterene. Bulky Ground-types like Ting-Lu and Donphan also benefit from Volcarona ability to somewhat safely switch into offensive Water-types such as Inteleon and non-Brave Bird Quaquaval. Volcarona is walled by common Well-Baked Body users like Kingambit and Corviknight, so attackers like Quaquaval and Sandy Shocks are helpful for breaking through them. Volcarona can also have trouble getting past Fire-resistant specially defensive walls that resist fire like Roaring Moon and Garganacl, so a physical wallbreaker such as Slither Wing is recommended.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Volcarona serves as a passable late-game sweeper after checks such as Well-Baked Body Corviknight and special walls such as Garganacl, Blissey, and Clodsire have been eliminated from the game. Volcarona wants to quickly rack up stat boosts with Quiver Dance and Fiery Dance to sweep the enemy team while also providing a Water immunity in the form of Desolate Land. Alternatively, Volcarona can opt for Storm Drain to turn fast Primordial Sea users such as Greninja and Barraskewda into setup fodder. Will-O-Wisp is preferred on the last slot to cripple physical attackers such as Garchomp and Quaquaval, which seek to exploit Volcarona's low Defense, but Volcarona can run Bug Buzz to threaten bulky phazers such as Ting-Lu and RegenVest Roaring Moon or Psychic to chunk Haze users such as Toxapex and Clodsire. Volcarona is completely walled by Well-Baked Body Steel-types such as Corviknight and Kingambit; thus, partners such as Sandy Shocks help to eliminate them in the early-game. While Giga Drain can hurt Garganacl, Volcarona's massive weakness to Rock means it doesn't want to stay into Garganacl at all; thus, teammates such as Magic Guard Quaquaval are particularly helpful. Lastly, Volcarona appreciates entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Clodsire, as the chip damage allows Volcarona to sweep more effectively.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Landorus-T is a specially defensive pivot with respectable offensive power to boot. Earthquake is its main STAB move, threatening offensive Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran and Iron Moth that fail to OHKO Landorus-T. U-turn allows Landorus-T to gain momentum and switch out, giving powerful-but-frail attackers like Chien-Pao and Iron Moth the ability to switch in for free. Rock Tomb and Sludge Bomb are used to whittle down Earth Eater Fire-types like Skeledirge and defensive Fairy-types like Scream Tail, respectively, with Rock Tomb being able to heavily damage Zapdos. Alternatively, Smack Down can be used to threaten switch-ins like Corviknight, (add comma) while Sandsear Storm can burn pivots like Garchomp. A Sassy nature with 0 Speed IVs lets Landorus-T underspeed defensive pivots like Garchomp, Scream Tail, and non-minimum Speed Corviknight with U-turn. RegenVest Landorus-T can form a powerful defensive VoltTurn core with physically defensive pivots like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Additionally, fast revenge killers and late-game sweepers like Chien-Pao and Hisuian Electrode benefit from slow pivots that can get them on the field without having to absorb an attack themselves. Due to its typing, Landorus-T does not act as an adequate switch-in to Water-type attackers like Volcanion; Water-resistant teammates like Dondozo and Water Absorb Iron Treads help mitigate this weakness.

sets.name: Fluffy
sets.description: Fluffy makes Landorus-T a decent defensive pivot that can take hits from physical attackers such as Slither Wing, Kingambit, and Ursaluna. Stealth Rock + Smack Down makes Landorus-T a decent entry hazard setter against Corviknight, the most common hazard removal option; Smack Down also ensures that Talonflame can't use Landorus-T as setup fodder. Taunt can also be used to deny recovery to Corviknight and Scream Tail and setup opportunities to foes, such as Talonflame and Roaring Moon. Landorus-T best fits on balance and bulky offense teams, where it can provide defensive support against the aforementioned physical attackers. Common defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, and Scream Tail are good teammates that can switch into Pokemon that threaten Landorus-T, such as Chien-Pao, Zapdos, and Quaquaval; Scream Tail can also provide Wish support. Landorus-T struggles to beat offensive Pokemon one-on-one, but its ability to safely pivot into teammates benefits fast offensive Pokemon such as Iron Moth, Greninja, and Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description: Primordial Sea Greninja can use its rain-boosted attacks to wallbreak with Choice Specs or serve as a valuable revenge killer and late-game cleaner with Choice Scarf, outspeeding boosted threats such as Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Sandy Shocks, and +1 Volcarona. Choice Specs-boosted Hydro Pump's higher power 2HKOes even Water-resistant foes such as Dondozo, and Quaquaval. U-turn lets it act as a solid offensive pivot, pairing extremely well with other offensive teammates like Hatterene and Armarouge that threaten its switch-in such as Toxapex, Desolate Land Iron Moth, and Roaring Moon. Greninja can run an entry hazard of choice since it forces multiple switches and threatens common hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight, whittling down its checks in the long run. Switcheroo immediately cripples its defensive checks as well as bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Scream Tail and Florges, especially for Choice Scarf variants that can't immediately harm them. Water Shuriken is a fringe option that can pick off weakened foes like Sandy Shocks and Chien-Pao. VoltTurn support from Pokemon such as Cinderace and Iron Moth is appreciated to bring Greninja in safely on foes like Garganacl.

sets.name: Magic Guard + Life Orb
sets.description: With high Speed that allows it to outspeed most of the unboosted metagame and Life Orb-boosted Special Attack, Greninja is a powerful special threat that uses its fantastic STAB combination to threaten common metagame threats like Ceruledge and Garganacl. Water Shuriken allows Greninja to reliably revenge kill weakened opponents and break through Substitute, while Ice Beam gives coverage against Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Garchomp. Greninja struggles against special walls like Florges and Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, so physically offensive Pokemon like Well Baked Body Kingambit and Ceruledge that can threaten them are good teammates. Due to its defensive frailty, Greninja also appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Cinderace that can safely pivot it in. Thanks to its immunity to entry hazards, Greninja fits well on offensive entry hazard stacking teams with little or no entry hazard removers.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Talonflame utilizes its great Speed tier, good power, and bevy of utility moves to function as one of the best late-game sweepers in the tier. Brave Bird's excellent power and neutral coverage allow Talonflame to effectively run mono-attacking sets while still forcing out most offensive Pokemon, like Meowscarada and Galarian Zapdos. Bulk Up provides insurance against revenge killers like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf users, while Swords Dance offers faster setup. Taunt is the preferred last move to take advantage of passive foes like Unaware Scream Tail and Well-Baked Body Corviknight, turning them into setup fodder; Will-O-Wisp provides team support by crippling bulky foes like Garganacl and Garchomp. Flare Blitz is a final option to provide coverage for Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads. Talonflame struggles with special Choice Scarf users like Sandy Shocks and Greninja, as they can force it out no matter how much it has set up, so teammates like Hisuian Goodra are excellent partners. Bulky Flying-resistant foes like Glimmora and Zapdos frustrate Talonflame, making teammates like Greninja and Garchomp that threaten them valuable. Talonflame truly shines in long games, as it can outlast its checks, so bulkier teammates like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Unaware Scream Tail that can help it get in multiple times are recommended.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Florges's extremely high Special Defense stat makes it an effective wall that also provides utility in the form of Wishpassing. With Unaware, Florges is able to comfortably set up on and check Pokemon such as Quiver Dance Volcarona, Fiery Dance Iron Moth, and Hatterene. Tablets of Ruin is also a viable option that allows Florges to easily switch into and threaten Pokemon such as Chien-Pao. Calm Mind + Wish and Synthesis give Florges the longevity necessary to serve a bulky sweeper. Wish + Protect provides guaranteed healing and can be used to scout options from foes; it also synergizes well with chip damage from other sources, like Garganacl's Salt Cure and poison damage from Toxic Spikes. Despite its naturally high Special Defense, Florges is threatened by special attackers that can muscle through it, such as Shell Smash Polteageist. Florges thus appreciates teammates that can handle these threats such as RegenVest Roaring Moon and Blissey. To compensate for its relatively low physical bulk, Florges can be paired with teammates who are more physically defensive, such as Dondozo and Corviknight.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Hisuian Goodra, with its excellent defensive typing and enormous special bulk, is a premier RegenVest user that is able to check common special attackers such as Zapdos, Hisuian Electrode, and Greninja while also being able to phase setup sweepers like Volcarona and Polteageist with Dragon Tail. Earthquake hits opposing Hisuian Goodra and can also OHKO Fire-types like Iron Moth, while Flamethrower can threaten Steel-types like Corviknight. Thunderbolt provides coverage for offensive Water-types like Greninja, Volcanion, and Inteleon while denying minimum Speed Corviknight an opportunity to use Roost; Draco Meteor is a strong STAB move for threats like Garchomp, and Ice Beam provides coverage against prominent special attackers like Zapdos, Hisuian Electrode, and Kilowattrel. Goodra is a great teammate for frail offensive Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Talonflame, as it can soak up hits from Choice Scarf revenge killers like Greninja and Azelf; in return, Zapdos and Talonflame can revenge kill strong special wallbreakers such as Thundurus-T and Hoopa, which could otherwise threaten Goodra. Goodra is vulnerable to strong physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Landorus-T, so pairing it with a physical wall such as Corviknight is recommended. Goodra can also be chipped down by entry hazards, which limit its walling prowess, so spinners like Quaquaval and Iron Treads make for good teammates to provide Goodra with more longevity.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: With a high Defense stat and solid utility movepool, Toxapex serves as a physical wall that checks threats such as Cinderace, Chien-Pao, and Quaquaval. With Prankster, Toxic allows Toxapex to stall out foes such as Ceruledge, using Haze to prevent them from setting up and Recover to stay healthy. Prankster + Haze is also an effective last resort against sweepers such as Shell Smash Polteageist and Belly Drum Hariyama, who can take over the game quickly. Alternatively, Toxic Spikes forces progress against the opponent. With Corrosion, Toxapex is able to use Toxic with impunity to guarantee poison damage, except Magic Guard users. Corrosion + Toxic is particularly effective against Corviknight, which commonly switches into Toxapex expecting to be immune to poison. However, pairing Toxic with Prankster means that Toxapex will be unable to poison Corviknight and Dark-type Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Roaring-Moon. Tablets of Ruin is also a viable option to allow Toxapex to stay in more comfortably against physical threats such as Meowscarada. Surf provides a decent STAB option to hit physical walls such as Corviknight, but Chilling Water can also be used in lieu of Liquidation to guarantee a lowered Attack stat. Iron Moth can threaten Toxapex and is also immune to poison damage, so a specially defensive partner like Garchomp is valuable.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Cinderace is a potent wallbreaker that can OHKO or 2HKO common defensive Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Kingambit. While Mold Breaker beats Well-Baked Body users like Corviknight, Desolate Land allows Cinderace to 2HKO even Fire-resistant Pokemon like Roaring Moon with Pyro Ball. Gunk Shot is a good option to hit Fairy-types like Scream Tail and Florges, while Sucker Punch allows Cinderace to revenge kill weakened opponents that outspeed it, such as Kilowattrel. Cinderace struggles against Primordial Sea users like Barraskewda and certain physical walls like Dondozo, so it appreciates teammates like Rotom-W that can threaten these Pokemon. Due to its low defensive stats and weakness to entry hazards, Cinderace appreciates pivoting and entry hazard removal from teammates like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Cinderace also pairs well with offensive pivots like Greninja, as they can easily maneuver around and threaten each other's checks.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Inteleon serves as a fast and powerful wallbreaker with its rain-boosted Hydro Pump that is able to 2HKO RegenVest Tinkaton and Garchomp and OHKO non-Water Abosrb Garganacl. It also boasts a good Speed tier that outpaces common offensive threats like Cinderace, Sandy Shocks, and Iron Moth. U-turn keeps up momentum against defensive answers like RegenVest Roaring Moon, and Mud Shot allows Inteleon to break Desolate Land Iron Moth. Ice Beam provides coverage against Dragon-types, Surf is a safer option when the raw power of Hydro Pump isn't needed, and Shadow Ball can OHKO Desolate Land Ghost-types in Skeledirge and Ceruledge. Inteleon struggles to break past the likes of RegenVest Roaring Moon and Desolate Land Volcarona, so it appreciates teammates such as Choice Band Slither Wing and offensive Iron Moth that can exploit these walls. Inteleon also partners up well with defensive pivots like Corviknight and RegenVest Roaring Moon that can safely pivot Inteleon in and also absorb attacks from revenge killers like Meowscarada and Kilowattrel.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Corviknight is simultaneously the best physical wall and Defogger in AAA, making it a staple on most teams. Intimidate is the preferred ability to better check Chien-Pao and potentially pass off a weakened attacker to a teammate, while Fluffy offers more overall walling potential against Galarian Zapdos and Kingambit; more rarely, immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Volt Absorb can be used, but they lack walling capabilities against neutral attackers. Brave Bird is its strongest available attack and threatens Galarian Zapdos, Slither Wing, and Quaquaval, while Body Press beats Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Corviknight is exceedingly passive on its own, but minimum Speed investment + U-turn allows it to bring in powerful offensive teammates like Slither Wing, Iron Moth, and Cinderace easily. RegenVest teammates like Meloetta and Hisuian Goodra cover the special attackers that like to come in on Corviknight, and they appreciate U-turn's extra chances to cycle in safely and gain additional Regenerator recovery. Corviknight is powerless to check dangerous physical Fire-types like Talonflame, Cinderace, and Ceruledge, making a secondary physical check like Garchomp or Well-Baked Body Iron Treads a good pairing. Corviknight needs to be at nearly 100% health to check foes like Galarian Zapdos and Chien-Pao, making secondary hazard removal options like Iron Treads and Quaquaval useful.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description: Prankster Corviknight’s excellent typing, solid bulk, and tailor-made movepool make it a premier dual screens lead for hyper offense teams. Taunt blocks entry hazards and denies setup attempts from opposing leads looking to capitalize on Corviknight’s passivity, while U-turn lets Corviknight, with its relatively low Speed, usually bring in a teammate safely. 64 Speed EVs outpace Prankster Spidops, allowing Corviknight to deny Sticky Web. Prankster Corviknight should be found exclusively on hyper offense teams with teammates like Volcarona, Zamazenta-C, and Chien-Pao that can take advantage of dual screens support to set up safely. Corviknight is unable to prevent Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Chien-Pao from setting hazards or setting up, so strong Fighting-type anti-leads like Slither Wing make excellent teammates.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Barraskewda is a devastating wallbreaker with a naturally high Speed tier to outpace the whole unboosted metagame, including fast threats like Chien-Pao and Kilowattrel. Close Combat pressures Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Desolate Land Chi-Yu and provides strong neutral coverage for Dondozo and Desolate Land Cinderace. Psychic Fangs and Drill Run cover foes such as Toxapex, Desolate Land Ceruledge, and Iron Moth; the latter's lesser power and accuracy is compensated for by hitting Desolate Land Ceruledge and OHKOing Cinderace. Aqua Jet revenge kills faster foes like boosted Volcarona and Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Sandy Shocks. Specially offensive pivots such as Iron Moth and Greninja can bring Barraskewda in safely on their switch-ins like Garganacl, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu for more wallbreaking opportunities. Late-game cleaners like Talonflame and Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks love Barraskewda pressuring the opposition early on; Sandy Shocks threatens problematic bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Toxapex in return.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description: Polteageist is a dangerous setup sweeper and cleaner thanks to Shell Smash, Stored Power, and its excellent Special Attack, allowing it to sweep with a single turn of setup. Giga Drain provides coverage for Ting-Lu and Garganacl, Strength Sap gives Polteageist a way to restore its Focus Sash after chip damage and set up on weaker physical attackers, while Substitute allows for safe setup on status-reliant walls like Blissey. Focus Sash the preferred item to safely ensure Polteageist can use Shell Smash. Polteageist can often struggle to get itself onto the field safely, so it appreciates a slow pivot from Corviknight or Shed Tail Cyclizar who can also facilitate Polteageist's setup with screens or a passed Substitute. Polteageist pairs well with physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Cinderace that can break through opposing walls. Due to its reliance on Focus Sash, Polteageist needs reliable entry hazard removal like Cyclizar and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Triage
sets.description: Hatterene is a decent Triage user that can successfully check dangerous attackers like Meowscarada, Greninja, and most Chien-Pao. Calm Mind and its good bulk allow it to set up and beat bulkier foes as well. Psyshock provides effectively mixed coverage, most notably beating Blissey. For the last moveslot, Mystical Fire beats non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight, Nuzzle cripples switch-ins like Kingambit, and Giga Drain hits Garganacl hard while providing more recovery and priority. Other sweepers benefit greatly from the dents placed by Hatterene, such as Shell Smash Polteageist and Quaquaval. Hatterene is weak to mainly priority-immune Chien-Pao and Shell Smash Polteageist. Kingambit, with or without RegenVest, is a reliable check to Polteageist. Corviknight is a solid partner, as it provides entry hazard removal and pivoting to safely bring Hatterene in. Hatterene also struggles with Fire-type Pokemon, making teammates like Garchomp and Well-Baked Body Kingambit naturally good partners.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description: With its great Speed and good coverage, Meowscarada is one of the best offense pivots in the tier, as Flower Trick + Knock Off provide excellent power, with Knock Off also frustrating common switch-ins like Corviknight. Alternatively, Choice Scarf sets let Meowscarada outspeed Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Hisuian Electrode, and Regieleki. Dazzling is a option over Sword of Ruin on Choice Scarf sets, letting Meowscarada deal with Slither Wing's First Impression and Ice Shard from Chien-Pao. For the last moveslot, Low Kick targets Kingambit, while Play Rough can potentially break Slither Wing; Power Gem is also a niche option on Choice Scarf sets to revenge kill Bulk Up Talonflame. Wallbreakers like Ceruledge and Iron Moth pair well with Meowscarada by punching holes into the opposing team so that Meowscarada can take over the game later on. Corviknight is also a fantastic partner for Meowscarada, tanking all of the Bug- and Ice-type moves, especially U-turn that threaten Meowscarada while also being able to pivot in Meowscarada safely. Meowscarada also pairs well with Pokemon such as Kingambit and Enamorus-T which appriciate Corviknight being weakened.

sets.name: Spinblocker
sets.description: Skeledirge is a premier spinblocker that is able to provide further utility in the form of type immunity. Earth Eater Skeledirge checks spinners such as Donphan and Iron Treads, while Water Absorb Skeledirge walls Quaquaval and Primordial Sea users such as Choice Band Barraskewda, allowing Skeledirge to use them as setup fodder or inflict them with burn. Skeledirge is additionally able to threaten Corviknight that seek to use Defog. Hex provides more damage when paired with burns inflicted by Will-O-Wisp, but Shadow Ball offers unconditional and reliable damage. Torch Song + Slack Off provides guaranteed stat boosts and healing, and when paired with Skeledirge's decent physical bulk, may allow it to serve as a bulky sweeper. Skeledirge wants to have teammates such as Clodsire and Ting-Lu that are able to set up entry hazards, as Skeledirge is excellent at keeping them on the field. Due to its low special bulk, Skeledirge is vulnerable to special wallbreakers such as Polteageist and Chi-Yu, so it appreciates teammates such as Blissey, who offer significant special bulk and speed control in the form of Thunder Wave. Earth Eater Skeledirge is vulnerable to Water-types such as Quaquaval, so it appreciates teammates such as Desolate Land Ceruledge and Rotom-Wash that can deal with them. Ground-types such as Clodsire and Ting-Lu give Water Absorb Skeledirge a difficult time, so team mates such as Chien-Pao and Greninja help it deal with them. Foes such as Well-Baked Body Corviknight and Kingambit also hinder Skeledirge, so pairing Skeledirge with Sandy Shocks or Quaquaval helps mitigate this matchup. Alternatively, teammates such as Ting-Lu can provide physical bulk and phazing support with Whirlwind, and Corviknight can check Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Meowscarada that hinder Skeledirge.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Quaquaval is a formidable offensive Pokemon that also uses its excellent typing and movepool to serve as the premier offensive entry hazard remover in the tier. Wave Crash is a powerful, drawback-free STAB move that deals heavy damage to foes lacking resistance to Water. Brave Bird is used to hit common Water move switch-ins, like Desolate Land users and opposing Quaquaval. Close Combat can be used as a powerful secondary STAB move and is useful for hitting Steel types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, but its drawbacks and typing leave Quaquaval vulnerable to Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Volcarona. Rapid Spin has fantastic synergy with Quaquaval's immunity to passive damage and ability to force out common hazard setters like Garchomp and Landorus-T; Quaquaval also appreciates the Speed boost and can use it in conjunction with Swords Dance to sweep later in the game. Roost greatly improves Quaquaval's longevity, allowing it to repeatedly check threats like Chien-Pao and Kingambit, while U-turn is used to safely bring in teammates after Quaquaval forces a switch. Quaquaval is hard to wear down thanks to Magic Guard, but its middling Speed and bulk leave it vulnerable to faster threats like Iron Moth, Zapdos, and Meowscarada. Fast, offensive teammates like Chien-Pao and Iron Moth appreciate Quaquaval's wallbreaking prowress and ability to remove hazards. Thanks to the passive damage immunity, Quaquaval excels as an offensive rapid spinner on hazard stacking teams, where teammates like Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Glimmora can set hazards without worrying about enemy hazards wearing them down.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Defensive Quaquaval uses its good physical bulk and typing to act as a physically defensive pivot, checking dangerous threats like Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Hisuian Arcanine. Intimidate allows Quaquaval to weaken foes like Chien-Pao and Cinderace for its teammates, while Fluffy grants better bulk to better check Slither Wing and Roaring Moon. U-turn allows Quaquaval to maintain momentum and allows frailer teammates like Slither Wing and Hydreigon to pivot in safely while Rapid Spin offers role compression by allowing it to remove hazards while having a good matchup against entry hazard setters like Iron Treads and Garchomp. A Relaxed nature and 0 Speed IVs allow it to pivot out as slow as possible. Meloetta is a valuable teammate that can switch in on special threats such as Iron Moth and Zapdos that force Quaquaval out. Physical wallbreakers like Meowscarada and Talonflame have a good type matchup against Quaquaval, hence teammates that can force them out like Zamazenta-C and Regieleki make solid partners.

sets.name: Sticky Web Setter
sets.description: Prankster Spidops is the optimal Sticky Web setter for hyper offense teams. Spikes and Toxic Spikes add more residual damage for opposing switch-ins, which can be valuable for securing KOs. Taunt is used to block setup and Defog, while Circle Throw forces switches and can rack up residual damage in combination with Spikes. Focus Sash is used to ensure that Spidops can get up Sticky Web and at least one layer of Spikes before fainting. Slow wallbreakers like Chi-Yu and Quaquaval appreciate the opportunities provided by Sticky Web support. Setup attackers such as Chien-Pao and Ceruledge also pair well with Spidops, as it enables them to outspeed would-be revenge killers. Spidops struggles to set Sticky Web against spinners, so it's recommended to pair Spidops with a Ghost-type like Earth Eater Skeledirge that can beat spinners like Iron Treads. Additionally, common Dark-types like Kingambit and Roaring Moon can set up on Spidops lacking Circle Throw, so pairing it with a strong Fighting type like Slither Wing is advised.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Pawmot leverages its potent typing that hits popular defensive staples such as Corviknight and Ting-Lu to serve as a powerful wallbreaker. Expert Belt capitalizes on Pawmot's great coverage, while Choice Band allows 2HKOs on neutral targets like Scream Tail and Skeledirge; alternatively, Magic Guard + Life Orb with Double Shock and Thunder Punch can also be used for similar neutral damage and the freedom to switch moves. Mach Punch allows Pawmot to beat faster offensive mons such as Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Greninja. Ice Punch allows Pawmot to reliably OHKO Garchomp and beat Clodsire, while Volt Switch can keep up momentum against defensive switch-ins such as Scream Tail and Fluffy Brambleghast. Jolly lets Pawmot outspeed Garchomp and non-Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks, while an Adamant nature bolsters its 2HKO chances on targets such as Scream Tail and Skeleridge with Choice Band Wild Charge. Pawmot often struggles to switch in safely, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Iron Treads that can safely pivot Pawmot in.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Garganacl is an incredibly reliable special wall. Sand Stream offers higher walling capabilities and forces extra chip damage on opponents, alternatively, Vessel of Ruin is a reliable option regardless of the weather. Stealth Rock supports its team with additional chip damage, and Protect can both scout opposing Choice-locked attackers and rack up Salt Cure damage; alternatively, IronPress threatens instant damage on foes, as well as boosts its Defense to better handle physical attackers like Kingambit. Earthquake hits opposing Garganacl and can offers progress against Magic Guard users, such as Greninja. Garganacl's best fit is on balance teams that want a reliable special wall and entry hazard support. Rocky Helmet Corviknight can also punish Iron Treads and Brambleghast for switching in and using Rapid Spin. Garganacl struggles to deal with Greninja and Rotom-W, as both can seriously threaten it, so a teammate like Desolate Land Iron Moth helps cover these weaknesses.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Garganacl serves as a solid physically defensive Pokemon that checks threats such as Chien-Pao and Cinderace with its natural bulk and typing. Levitate notably prevents Garganacl from being worn down by Spikes and Toxic Spikes, but Earth Eater is an option on teams with reliable entry hazard control. Salt Cure chips switch-ins like Corviknight and Dondozo. The listed setup and coverage moves enable Garganacl to accomplish feats like winning the one-on-one against Kingambit with Curse or IronPress, racking up chip damage with Salt Cure + Protect, and hitting Fluffy Dondozo with Earthquake on the switch-in. Garganacl benefits from teammates such as Desolate Land Volcarona and Iron Moth, which check Water-type threats such as Quaquaval and Greninja. It's also recommended to pair Garganacl with Pokemon that can account for Rapid Spin users such as Iron Treads, so teammates like Decidueye and Brambleghast are great choices.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Armarouge is a passable revenge killer that outspeeds naturally fast Pokemon like Cinderace and Chien-Pao, threatening them with its high-Base Power STAB attacks. Moreover, it can clean up late-game easily thanks to Psychic Surge, which protects it from common priority attacks such as Slither Wing's First Impression and Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Trick cripples bulky foes it can't immediately threaten like Blissey, Florges, and Garganacl. Focus Blast hits Chi-Yu and Roaring Moon, while Psyshock 2HKOes Clodsire. Utility moves in Destiny Bond and Will-O-Wisp can also be used, with the former checking setup sweepers like Talonflame and the latter punishing switch-ins. Wallbreakers like Greninja can overwhelm shared checks and appreciate Armarouge's Psychic Terrain protecting them from the likes of Ceruledge's Shadow Sneak. Armarouge's susceptibility to entry hazards makes teammates like Defog Corviknight and Rapid Spin Iron Treads valuable options.

sets.name: Sword of Ruin
sets.description: Ceruledge is a strong wallbreaker with its typing, good coverage, and high Attack. Sword of Ruin-boosted Bitter Blade is a strong STAB move that OHKOes most Pokemon in the tier after a Swords Dance and can break sturdy checks like defensive Garchomp; additionally, the HP recovery is useful for counteracting chip from Life Orb and entry hazards. Shadow Sneak makes up for Ceruledge's below-average Speed by allowing it to pick off weakened threats such as Cinderace and Iron Moth. Close Combat deals with Fire-resistant foes like Roaring Moon and Garganacl. Due to Ceruledge's frail defensive stats and entry hazard susceptibility, it appreciates entry hazard removal and pivoting from teammates like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Greninja and Kilowattrel help Ceruledge handle fast offensive threats like Meowscarada and Zapdos, while Ceruledge can break past common RegenVest foes such as Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta that they could otherwise struggle with.

sets.name: Primordial Sea
sets.description: Primordial Sea Kilowattrel is a powerful threat with excellent Speed, strong weather-boosted moves, great coverage, and pivoting. Naturally outspeeding most common threats except Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, Kilowattrel can safely pivot or threaten massive damage against the entire tier. Choice Specs 2HKOes fully invested Ting-Lu and Clodsdire with Weather Ball. U-turn provides safe pivoting with no immunities, while Volt Switch is significantly stronger and provides important coverage if forgoing Thunder. Kilowattrel excels in VoltTurn cores, while also acting as a sweeper in the right scenarios, making other pivots such as Roaring Moon and Cinderace excellent partners. Powerful cleaners like Choice Band Meowscarada appreciate Kilowattrel checking their common Steel-type switch-ins, and setup attackers mesh well with Kilowattrel’s ability to OHKO Corviknight. Kilowattrel is extremely weak to common priority users like Chien-Pao making sturdy physical walls like Intimidate Garganacl great partners. Defensive pivots like Corviknight and Iron Treads also provide much needed Stealth Rock removal, if running Choice Specs.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Brambleghast boasts several attributes that make it a ideal choice on hazard stacking teams; its typing is ideal for spinblocking in the face of Donphan, Iron Treads, and Quaquaval, and it offers role compression in Spikes and Rapid Spin. Giga Drain allows Brambleghast to force out Dondozo as well as the aforementioned Rapid Spin users, and Fluffy further enhances its ability to beat such threats. Alternatively, Triage lets it pick off weakened sweepers like Greninja and Sandy Shocks, as well safely use Strength Sap against faster foes. Brambleghast appreciates partners such as Kilowattrel and Sandy Shocks, who threaten Corviknight and dissuade it from using Defog, letting Brambleghast's team maintain entry hazards in the face of both Rapid Spin and Defog. Poison-types like Iron Moth removing Toxic Spikes let Brambleghast not have to worry about switching into Knock Off and getting its Heavy-Duty Boots removed.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Tinkaton is a solid Stealth Rock setter with decent bulk that can check common special attackers such as Hydreigon, Hatterene, and Scream Tail while also crippling common switch-ins like Corviknight and Garchomp with Knock Off. Encore can be used to PP stall recovery moves such as Roost on Corviknight and setup moves on Scream Tail, Gigaton Hammer is a strong STAB move for targets like Scream Tail and Hatterene, and Ice Hammer can be used to threaten Garchomp. Earth Eater can be used as an alternative ability to check Ground-types like Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Sandy Shocks more effectively. Physical attackers that can have a hard time breaking Corviknight like Kingambit and Roaring Moon appreciate Tinkaton's Knock Off and Thunder Wave. Additionally, Hex users like Skeledirge also appreciate Tinkaton's ability to spread status and allow them to fully capitalize on a boosted Hex while also being able to outspeed paralyzed foes. Tinkaton can struggle with strong special attackers like Inteleon and Iron Moth, so pairing it with a strong specially defensive wall like Roaring Moon or Iron Moth is recommended.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Tinkaton's decent bulk with Assault Vest and incredible defensive typing allow it to pivot into and check special attackers such as Hatterene and Hydreigon. Knock Off is Tinkaton's most important move, as it provides utility by removing crucial items from common switch-ins such as Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Iron Treads. Skitter Smack lowers the Special Attack of bulky Calm Mind users such as Florges and powerful wallbreakers such as Chi-Yu, allowing Tinkaton and its teammates to more easily handle these threats. Play Rough and Ice Hammer both hit Dragon-types such as Roaring Moon hard; Play Rough also dents Fighting-types such as Slither Wing while Ice Hammer deals huge damage to Garchomp and Clodsire. Physically defensive walls such as Hippowdon can deal with the physical wallbreakers that threaten Tinkaton, like Ceruledge, and appreciate it relieving pressure against Greninja. Slower attackers such as Chi-Yu and Quaquaval benefit from Tinkaton handling fast revenge killers such as Kilowattrel for them.

sets.name: Palafin
sets.description: Palafin's powerful priority offense and pivoting make it a dangerous threat even with its standard ability. Jet Punch from Palafin-H easily revenge kills dangerous threats like Kilowattrel, Sandy Shocks, and Talonflame, as well as Chien-Pao after minor chip damage. Palafin is heavily hampered by Desolate Land; to take down their users, Zen Headbutt from Palafin-H easily OHKOes Iron Moth and 2HKOes Ceruledge, while Close Combat flings Cinderace into the sun. Pivoting teammates such as Kilowattrel, Meowscarada, and Corviknight not only form dangerous pivoting cores with Palafin, but also position it to both activate Zero to Hero and fire off its powerful Jet Punch. Due to its frequent need to switch and reliance on a recoil move to wallbreak, Palafin requires effective entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Donphan; WishPass Scream Tail is also a great teammate to heal off chip damage. Even with its strong coverage moves, Palafin struggles mightily against opposing Desolate Land, so reliable switch-ins like Well-Baked Body Slither Wing are strongly recommended. Palafin struggles against Dondozo, making teammates that can punish it like Meowscarada and Spikes Garchomp good additions.

sets.name: Shed Tail
sets.description: Shed Tail, Regenerator, and good Speed give Cyclizar a unique role on offensive teams: safely bringing in powerful attackers like Cinderace and Polteageist multiple times per battle. Draco Meteor KOes opposing Cyclizar and picks off weakened foes. U-turn lets Cyclizar pivot out without self-damage, healing from Regenerator to potentially use Shed Tail again later. Rapid Spin and/or Knock Off provide further utility. Choice Scarf + Shed Tail is preferred against Chien-Pao and other fast threats, but Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to avoid entry hazard damage and the Choice lock. Cyclizar benefits greatly from a strong physical wall or Dazzling user to deal with priority attackers like Hatterene. Strong attackers like Cinderace and Greninja are also valuable for dealing with phazers like Hippowdon and Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: A pure Water typing, titanic physical bulk, and Tablets of Ruin make Dondozo a nearly impenetrable physical wall that can blanket check common physical attackers including Cinderace, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao. Other options like Unaware can be used to ignore setup sweepers and wallbreakers that attempts to boost past Dondozo, while Magic Guard prevents it from being overwhelmed by entry hazards, Toxic, and Wave Crash recoil. Aside from turning it into a bulky setup sweeper, Curse also lets Dondozo contest with opposing setup from the likes of Talonflame and Kingambit, especially on non-Unaware variants. Earthquake is a necessary coverage move to hit Toxapex and Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Ceruledge. Rest + Leftovers provide much needed longevity, with Rest preventing Dondozo from being permanently crippled by Clodsire's Toxic, Iron Moth's Toxic Spikes, and Volcarona and Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp. Special walls such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Corviknight are necessary to deal with special attackers like Iron Moth, Sandy Shocks, and Chi-Yu respectively; the former three spread further passive damage onto foes between entry hazards, Toxic, Ruination, and Salt Cure, slowly whittling down foes for Dondozo to sweep easier. In return, Dondozo covers the likes of Quaquaval and Cinderace for them.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Tatsugiri is a decent Nasty Plot user that is able to threaten slower foes with its powerful STAB moves and it provides further utility by functioning as a spinner for teams that appreciate more hazard control. Magic Guard affords Tatsugiri some additional safety from entry hazards and chip damage from the likes of Salt Cure and Toxic. Instead of Hydro Pump, Surf can be used for more reliability. Tatsugiri is able to come in on and threaten spinblockers such as Skeledirge and Brambleghast, allowing it to use Nasty Plot or Rapid Spin on prediction. If left unchecked, Tatsugiri may be able to rack up enough boosts from Nasty Plot + Rapid Spin to serve as a frail sweeper. Due to its mediocre physical bulk, Tatsugiri appreciates physical walls such as Corviknight, which can also serve as a slow pivot to bring Tatsugiri safely into a favorable matchup. Tatsugiri also pairs well with physical attackers, such as Cinderace, that can threaten special walls such as Florges and Blissey, which Tatsugiri struggles against. Tatsugiri also appreciates entry hazards or other chip damage to secure KOs that it would typically miss, so Garganacl, with its ability to use Salt Cure and Stealth Rock, is a helpful teammate. Due to its low Speed, Tatsugiri appreciates faster teammates that can act as speed control, such as Chien-Pao or priority users such as Hatterene.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: A unique defensive typing, reliable recovery, and remarkable special bulk enhanced by Vessel of Ruin allow Clodsire to check prominent special attackers like Iron Moth and Hydreigon. Toxic can cripple Heavy-Duty Boots users like Volcarona and Kilowattrel. Corrosion + Toxic notably hits Corviknight and Toxapex, which are common switch ins and wears them down. Toxic Spikes and Poison Jab are better on Prankster sets to punish Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Ting-Lu; in particular, Toxic Spikes lets Clodsire match up well against hyper offense teams filled with setup sweepers. Prankster + Haze allows Clodsire to shut down setup sweepers, like Volcarona and Polteageist, while they whittle down from poison damage. Pokemon like Garganacl and Scream Tail form a hazard-stacking core with Clodsire. Physical walls like the aforementioned Pokemon, Corviknight, and Dondozo handle physical threats such as Quaquaval and Earth Eater Kingambit that can exploit Clodsire's poor physical bulk.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Kingambit excels as a mid-game wallbreaker that can boost on passive foes and tear through the opponent's team with its Adaptability-boosted STAB attacks. Kowtow Cleave and Iron Head are Kingambit's main attacks, heavily damaging defensive pivots like Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, Scream Tail, and Garganacl. Sucker Punch lets it predict and punish faster attackers like Quaquaval, Volcarona, and Slither Wing that try and come in to revenge kill. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed uninvested Corviknight and Skeledirge. Black Glasses lets Kingambit OHKO Iron Moth with Sucker Punch. Immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater are options to pick up additional setup chances. Fast endgame sweepers like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Hisuian Electrode benefit from Kingambit's early-game presence, capitalizing on chipped foes and scoring easy KOs. Defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Fluffy Landorus-T can thwart revenge killers targeting Kingambit and use U-turn to bring it in safely again. Finally, Primordial Sea Zapdos can help Kingambit by forcing Corviknight and Quaquaval, two of its most consistent checks, letting it chip them on their switch-in repeatedly.

sets.name: Unaware
sets.description: Unaware Scream Tail is a premier defensive threat in the metagame, capable of walling foes such as Azelf, Roaring Moon, and Quaquaval, stonewalling most setup attempts, and being a powerful wincon. Wish + Protect is vital to ensure Scream Tail's health throughout the match, and it is also useful for healing teammates like Kingambit and Slither Wing, which often lack recovery of their own and are prone to being chipped down throughout a match. Calm Mind is suggested to ensure Scream Tail can become a late-game wincon, but Thunder Wave can be run instead as further team support for Hex users like Skeledirge and Hisuian Typhlosion. Encore and Stealth Rock can also be used for further protection against setup sweepers and role compression, respectively. Unaware ensures it can check boosted foes like Chien-Pao and opposing Calm Mind users like Triage Enamorus-T. 20 Speed EVs ensure it will always outspeed Hoopa, Volcanion, and Adamant Slither Wing. Scream Tail is taken advantage of by common Steel-, Fire-, and Poison-types like Hisuian Goodra, Hisuan Arcanine, and Iron Moth, so switch-ins to them like Heatran, Garchomp, and Alolan Muk are recommended; they also benefit from Scream Tail's Wish. Teammates that are weak to Fighting- and Psychic-type attacks like Iron Treads and Galarian Zapdos greatly appreciate Scream Tail's ability to switch into them.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Slither Wing leverages its large base Attack and STAB Close Combat, U-turn, and First Impression to serve as an extremely potent wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. Flare Blitz is preferred on Tinted Lens sets, allowing it to 2HKO Intimidate and Fluffy Corviknight, while Earthquake is an option to hit checks like non-Earth Eater Skeledirge and Toxapex when running Sword of Ruin. Tinted Lens better allows Slither Wing to revenge kill foes, do more damage to switch-ins with U-turn, and more easily break potential checks like Zapdos and Toxapex while Sword of Ruin grants more overall power for neutral targets such as Fluffy Quaquaval. Slither Wing pairs well with special wallbreakers like Magic Guard Hisuian Electrode and Hydreigon, which can threaten Slither Wing's checks and pivot it in on special walls for it to break. Faster offensive cleaners like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada also pair well with Slither Wing for their ability to handle fast threats and overload physical walls. Defensive pivots like Corviknight and Iron Treads also partner well with Slither Wing, as they're able to safely pivot Slither Wing it in to break wallbreak, and they also absorb revenge killing attempts; furthermore, they are particularly useful for their ability to remove entry hazards, which wear down Slither Wing quickly throughout a game as it pivots frequently.

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Cinderace, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Iron Moth and Hydreigon, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and the former can also fire off Terrain-boosted Discharge. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

sets.name: Regenerator Pivot
sets.description: RegenVest Iron Treads is a great specially defensive pivot and spinner. It is able to switch into prominent special attackers such as Hatterene and threaten them out. Knock Off removes key items like Heavy-Duty Boots and deters spinblockers from switching in, and Volt Switch has excellent synergy with Regenerator. If its teammates already provide adequate entry hazard control, Iron Head and Ice Spinner are options to target Scream Tail and Garchomp, respectively. A Sassy nature with minimum Speed investment ensures the slowest possible pivot with Volt Switch. Iron Treads appreciates physically defensive teammates like Slowking, which can form a VoltTurn core to bring in powerful-but-frail teammates like Noivern and Cinderace.

sets.name: Sheer Force
sets.description: With high-Base Power moves and decent Special Attack and Speed, Iron Jugulis is a solid wallbreaker that can outspeed and threaten common specially defensive foes, like Garchomp and Garganacl. Iron Jugulis offers a notable niche, as Hurricane + Dark Pulse + Focus Blast can hit every viable Pokemon for neutral damage. Taunt disrupts attempts to heal, set up, or set entry hazards, allowing Iron Jugulis to better handle Pokemon such as Blissey and Clodsire. Iron Jugulis struggles against special walls like Florges and Scream Tail, so physically offensive teammates like Cinderace and Ceruledge are necessary to break through them. Due to its frailty, it enjoys teammates like Slither Wing and Corviknight that can pivot it in, the latter of which can also remove hazards with Defog. Iron Jugulis also appreciates entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu, which can enable it to secure KOs that it would typically miss, such as Garganacl.

sets.name: All Out Attacker
sets.description: Iron Moth is a potent and aggressive special attacker with access to relevant STAB attacks and convenient coverage options. Flamethrower and Sludge Wave help Iron Moth dispatch of Almost Any Ability's staple Steel- and Fairy-types like Corviknight and Scream Tail as well as outputting massive damage to anything that doesn't resist its attacks. Fire Blast can be used for more damage output, outdamaging RegenVest Meloetta and Hisuian Goodra's Regenerator healing. Energy Ball can be used instead of Sludge Wave to help Iron Moth's matchup with Well-Baked Body Iron Treads and Regenerator Ting-Lu. Dazzling Gleam improves Iron Moth's offensive chances against Dragon-types like Garchomp and Roaring Moon. Discharge is a coverage alternative that hits Well-Baked Body Corviknight as well as becoming a monstrously strong offensive option when combined with Iron Moth's alternate ability, Hadron Engine. Additionally, Hadron Engine helps Iron Moth score a 2HKO on specially defensive Garchomp with Dazzling Gleam. Balance and offense teams that appreciate explosive offensive power look forward to having Iron Moth as a teammate, as it can easily wipe some defensive pivots like Corviknight and Scream Tail off of the opponent's team. Additionally, Iron Moth struggles heavily against special walls like Garchomp, Garganacl, and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, so heavy hitters like Kingambit and Slither Wing can be used to make progress against these, making it easier for Iron Moth to sweep late-game. Finally, tools found on hyper offense teams like dual screens, Sticky Web, and entry hazard stacking help Iron Moth more effectively avoid revenge killers and more easily eliminate any of its switch-ins.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: With its incredible Attack and a near-unparalleled Speed tier, Chien-Pao excels as a revenge killer and late-game sweeper that can easily dispatch weakened defensive foes. Icicle Crash and Crunch are its main offensive options, threatening common pivots like Garchomp and Skeledirge; Icicle Crash also bypasses Fluffy. Sacred Sword picks up an OHKO on Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra, Heatran, and Kingambit while also threatening physical walls like Zamazenta-C and Garganacl. Ice Shard lets Chien-Pao revenge kill Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Hisuian Electrode, as well as Agility or Dragon Dance users like Galarian Moltres or Roaring Moon. This Pokemon is often paired with defensive entry hazard setters and slow, defensive pivots that can allow it to switch in freely. For example, Corviknight has both a slow U-turn to pivot Chien-Pao in freely and Defog to remove hazards. Additionally, Rapid Spin users like Iron Treads can clear the opponent's hazards, which punish Chien-Pao for switching in. Finally, bulky wallbreakers and Fire-type attackers like Kingambit or Ceruledge help Chien-Pao deal with physically defensive Steel-types, like Tinkaton and Intimidate Corviknight, weakening them and making Chien-Pao's job as an endgame cleaner more efficient.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Chien-Pao is a strong wallbreaker thanks to its high Attack and excellent STAB combination accompanied by a blazing fast Speed tier that outpaces all unboosted Pokemon bar Regieleki, Hisuian Electrode, and Barraskewda. It breaks holes in the opponent's defensive core for teammates like Roaring Moon and Kingambit to exploit, or it can sweep when a teammate like Garchomp or Zamazenta has weakened its checks.
